awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Coupled Hydrology and Mechanics of Fine-Grained Soils and Sedimentary Rocks
awd_abstract_narration:
Fine-grained rocks (shale, mudstone) exist as caprocks, host rocks, and source rocks for a range of subsurface water, energy, and carbon resources.  They also represent a control on carbon capture and storage, high-level radioactive waste storage, groundwater sources and storage and shale hydrocarbon extraction. Fine-grained soils play an equally important role in agriculture and soil carbon storage. This importance of clay-rich media derives largely from their distinct hydrologic and mechanical properties (ultra-low permeability, swelling-shrinking and cracking). These properties are of singular importance in controlling fluid flow in the subsurface (where fine-grained rocks constitute roughly two-thirds of the sedimentary rock mass), yet they remain a sparsely charted frontier research area in groundwater hydrology.
 

This project will develop a general theory of the hydrologic properties of fine-grained soils and sedimentary rocks. This goal requires understanding the coupled hydrologic, mechanical, and chemical properties of porous media on multiple scales, from the nanometer scale (where aggregation and swelling of clay particles takes place) to the 10-100s of meters that control the bulk mechanical and flow properties of the rock. The proposed research relies on a combination of simulation methodologies adapted to each length scale of interest, along with rigorous experimental validations at each scale. Key projected outcomes include detailed fundamental understanding of the meso- and nanoscale properties of fine-grained media and new constitutive relations describing the coupled hydrologic-mechanical-chemical properties of these media. The major education and outreach goal is to develop the use of molecular dynamics simulations as a pedagogical tool that can illustrate the fundamental basis of important scientific concepts and phenomena in an intuitive, and hands-on manner. This tool will be developed for both first year of the Environmental Engineering undergraduate curriculum and as part of a web-based interface (a Science Gateway) that will enable the broader community (e.g., high school students and teachers) to visualize and explore simulation results stored on the high-performance data storage systems at the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center (NERSC).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new knowledge of how clay, a ubiquitous natural material, impacts the hydraulic and mechanical properties of soils, sediments, and sedimentary rocks.  This knowledge is foundational to efforts to predict a range of hydro-mechanical phenomena, including erosion, liquefaction, consolidation, subsidence, mudslides, debris flow, and geological CO2 storage security. The project focused particularly on understanding key length scales associated with the interactions between clay nanoparticles (nanometers to micrometers), the ductile deformation of the clay matrix (micrometers to millimeters), and the formation of cracks that can impact larger-scale fluid flow and mechanics (millimeters to meters). Approaches developed in this project were based on a combination of simulations that used high-performance computing clusters to represent clay-rich media across the wide range of length scales of interest.

Intellectual Merit:

The project generated several methodological advances. One was the development of a new computational fluid dynamics (CFD) framework to represent fluid flow and solid mechanics in materials that contain open space (such as fractures) and a deformable microporous matrix (such as clay). This framework, developed for both single and multiphase flow, was shown to be capable of representing complex phenomena including the formation of cracks associated with multiphase flow in clay and other poroviscoplastic solids, with appropriate coupling between the hydraulics and mechanics.

Another methodological advance was the development of a new coarse-grained molecular dynamics (MD) model capable of predicting the microstructure of assemblages of hydrated clay nanoparticles (such as clay flocs or compacted clay). This new framework, parameterized based on all-atom MD simulations carried out on US Department of Energy supercomputers, successfully predicts emergent features of assemblages of large numbers of clay particles such as the existence of a bimodal pore-size distribution in compacted clay under well-established conditions.

Broader Impacts:

The hydro-mechanical properties of clayey media play important roles in a wide variety of natural processes, including many geophysical hazards (erosion, mudslides, etc.). These properties also are important in evaluating the feasibility of clay-rich rocks (shales or mudstones) as sealing formations for the geologic sequestration of CO2 or high-level radioactive waste. Fundamental understanding of the mechanics of poroviscoplastic materials generated in this study also has broader implications, for example, for our ability to represent the morphology and growth of bacterial biofilms under flow, a persistent problem in the mitigation of chronic infections. 

The new CFD simulation frameworks developed as part of this study have been shared via GitHub to facilitate future examinations of the hydromechanical properties of poroviscoplastic or poroelastic materials by other research groups. The new coarse-grained MD model also will be shared via GitHub to facilitate future coarse-grained simulations of hydrated clay assemblages containing thousands of clay nanoparticles.

The project led to the development of two workshops hosted by the Princeton Center for Theoretical Science (PCTS). The first, a three-day workshop in January 2019 on Transport in Disordered Environments, involved about 90 participants. The second, a three-day workshop in January 2022 on Physics in the Ground Beneath our Feet, involved about 100 participants and resulted in a draft manuscript that will be submitted to the journal Soft Matter.

To date, results of this project have been disseminated as two PhD theses, six peer-reviewed publications (with a seventh in preparation), two GitHub repositories (with a third in preparation), 22 invited presentations (including two by graduate students supported by this project), and 18 contributed papers at scientific meetings (including 12 by graduate students supported by this project). The project contributed to the training of two doctoral students and three undergraduate students, including two female students and one under-represented minority (URM) student. More broadly, over the five years of this project, the PI mentored 30 undergraduate students (including 63% female students and 30% URM students) in the framework of 16 senior theses, 19 summer internships, and nine semester-long undergraduate research projects.
